comments.body:
We could simplify it:
```
case Some(char) if charIsPipe(char) =>
   val secondPipeIndex = lineText.indexOf('|', firstPipeIndex + 1)
   val secondPipePos = new Position(line, secondPipeIndex)
   new TextEdit(new Range(zeroPos, secondPipePos), defaultIndent)
case _ =>
  val pipePos = new Position(line, firstPipeIndex)
  new TextEdit(new Range(zeroPos, pipePos), defaultIndent)
```

The same with the other match
Ahh, yea, that is much nicer. I appreciate all the input!

comments.body: What happens if the line doesnâ€™t have a pipe? Itâ€™s optional

If there is no pipe on the line it gets filtered out beforehand and the line never enters the `formatPipeLine` method. I suppose I should have added a test for this as well. I did just check it locally and that indeed is how it works.
I just added another test for this https://github.com/scalameta/metals/pull/1249

comments.body: Since we check previously if there is a pipe in the line, the lastPipe inex will be correct.

If I understand this correctly, this isn't needed here since we can just calculate starting at the position start rather then the position start -1 to determine the last index between the new line and the position start. This is what was throwing the exception when we were trying to get the index using the value here, which was -1 when in the beginning of the file.
We probably just need `Math.max(pos.start - 1, 0)`
I'm working on a fix for #1477, so I'll include the fix for both in another pr.

When pressing enter we search for `newLineBeforePos`(where our newline was added). Then we search for '\n' before that and assign it to `pipeSearchStop` and it gives us a range [pipeSearchStop, newLineBeforePos] which is our previous line. Then we check if it contains '|' and if that is the case we do formatting(add '|' in current line properly aligned).

In current code it fails because it starts to search `pipeSearchStop` from position -1, I think we should simply add `Math.max(0, xxx - 1)` in both cases where we do search for \n
@tgodzik you were faster with a comment, ignore mine :P
unused variable after changes
Thanks! Removed.

I don't think the change is needed, although it does look nicer. We previously used `while` to be sure that we are as optimized as possible and we don't create any additional objects, so maybe we should keep it? I am not 100 % sure if that is super needed, but I would feel saver about it.

comments.body:
Could we maybe operate or indexes here?
Find the right line and then check `"` until the next `\n`?

It might be more efficient to not use split on the whole file. I am worried about the performance with large files.

Or alternatively, we could create a method `findLine` that would just do the substring on the needed line. What do you think?

We are splitting both here and in `doubleQuoteNotClosed` 

Maybe we can calculate `lineBefore` only once?
ok. maybe the class MultilineStringFormattingProvider, could have the lines of the current file.. so the split and all if these operations are only done once?
